fields.description:
Syncing users from user directories (such as JIRA), does not check to see if the users contain unsupported characters (i.e. / and +). As such, this causes problems with FishEye/Crucible, especially in the {{People}} menu.

Steps to reproduce:
# Create a user in JIRA with unsupported characters (i.e. dav/e+)
# Sync the users from JIRA to FishEye.
fields.summary: Syncing Users Allows Unsupported Characters

fields.description:
I have a JIRA project that uses the Simple Issue Tracking Workflow: a Done transition moves an issue to the completed/finished/done state.

JIRA fails to record the comment included with a workflow command.
According to the [smart commits documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Using+smart+commits], I should be able to issue a workflow command that also records a comment.

Observed behavior: adding {{#done Fixed the mistake}} to a commit causes JIRA to transition the issue to the done state, but it fails to record the comment.
fields.summary: Comment text is ignored when transitioning a bug with #done

fields.summary: Rest API "permissions" not working

fields.description:
If I set a Start Revision when indexing a SVN repository FishEye will list files for which last changes occurred prior to the Start Revision, but the revision listed for the file will be one revision before it. 

Example:
# I have a *readme* file for which last change occurred in revision 33:
{noformat}
grefosco@ecrmac-32 highlight-test $ svn log readme 
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r33 | grefosco | 2014-01-29 18:54:42 -0200 (Wed, 29 Jan 2014) | 1 line

changing readme
{noformat}
# I set the *Start Revision* for the repository as *36*, *Initial Import* as *Do not import*.
# For FishEye 3.0.3 the file is listed as having *no_author* in the *Author* column, and *Revision* column displays *35* (also for other files with older changes):
!files.png|thumbnail!
# In FishEye 3.5.3 the author is properly listed, and the *Revision* column displays *36*.

This may lead to some confusions.
fields.summary: Files last changed prior to the Start Revision are listed with the wrong revision

fields.description:
FishEye attempts to detect an incorrectly configured svn password by measuring the number of svn requests for a password within a 10 second window. If this exceeds 10, the password attempt is rejected which fails the svn operation. This is normally not a problem but when viewing the patch, the UI launches a number of svn cat operations in separate UI requests. These execute in parallel which causes the count to exceed the limit. The limit needs to be applied per thread.

fields.description:
Currently, "When FishEye indexes a Git repository, it indexes by the available branches. As it processes the commits on a branch, FishEye will assign the commit to the branch it first sees the commit on. Commits are only indexed once so if a commit belongs to multiple branches, the commit will not be indexed against subsequent branches." there([source|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Git]).

It would be nice to have FishEye index commits on multiple branches. This way looking at a commit will show all of the branches that it is involved in.
fields.summary: Allow FishEye to index Git commits on multiple branches

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If FishEye/Crucible is configure with Native Subversion Client and the Subversion server is using NTLM authentication, FishEye/Crucible does not cache the credential of the user in the repository setting.

h3. Actual Results
FishEye/Crucible keeps on getting the password from the repository setting till it hit the maximum count ("SVN is requesting password too often"). When it hits the maximum count getting the password, FishEye/Crucible will not get the password from the repository setting anymore causing the request to have authentication error:
{noformat}
2014-08-29 06:56:03,097 DEBUG [SvnExecution1 subversion ] fisheye SvnTask$1-run - Executing svn cat -r 1 http://subversion/trunk/test.xml@1
2014-08-29 06:56:03,128 DEBUG [SvnExecution1 subversion ] fisheye SvnPasswordSupplier-prompt - prompting for realm: <http://subversion:80> Subversionserver with username: klfoong, maySave = true
2014-08-29 06:56:03,128 DEBUG [SvnExecution1 subversion ] fisheye SvnPasswordSupplier-getPassword - Getting password
2014-08-29 06:56:03,431 DEBUG [SvnExecution1 subversion ] fisheye SvnTask$1-run - Executing svn proplist -r 1 http://subversion/trunk/test2.xml@1
2014-08-29 06:56:03,447 DEBUG [SvnExecution1 subversion ] fisheye SvnPasswordSupplier-prompt - prompting for realm: <http://subversion:80> Subversionserver with username: klfoong, maySave = true
2014-08-29 06:56:03,462 WARN  [SvnExecution1 subversion ] fisheye SvnPasswordSupplier-prompt - SVN is requesting password too often for realm '<http://subversion:80> Subversionserver' and user 'klfoong'
2014-08-29 06:56:03,462 DEBUG [InitPing2 subversion ] fisheye Timer-output - <- Processing diff paths for 1  time 2928 millis mem_usage = 196793096 heapsize = 439681024 freemem = 242887928
2014-08-29 06:56:03,462 DEBUG [InitPing2 subversion ] fisheye BaseRevisionCache-withDbWriteLock - Rolling back for priority 40
2014-08-29 06:56:03,462 ERROR [InitPing2 subversion ] fisheye BaseRepositoryScanner-handleSlurpException - Problem processing revisions from repo fa due to class com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryClientException - org.apache.subversion.javahl.ClientException: Authorization failed
svn: Unable to connect to a repository at URL 'http://subversion/trunk/test2.xml'
svn: OPTIONS of 'http://subversion/trunk/test2.xml': authorization failed: Could not authenticate to server: ignored NTLM challenge, rejected Basic challenge (http://subversion)
com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryClientException: org.apache.subversion.javahl.ClientException: Authorization failed
svn: Unable to connect to a repository at URL 'http://subversion/trunk/test2.xml'
svn: OPTIONS of 'http://subversion/trunk/test2.xml': authorization failed: Could not authenticate to server: ignored NTLM challenge, rejected Basic challenge (http://subversion)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.svn.SvnThrottledClient.executeNoThrottle(SvnThrottledClient.java:186)
	at com.cenqua.fisheye.svn.SvnThrottledClient.execute(SvnThrottledClient.java:155)
Caused by: org.apache.subversion.javahl.ClientException: Authorization failed
svn: Unable to connect to a repository at URL 'http://subversion/trunk/test2.xml'
svn: OPTIONS of 'http://subversion/trunk/test2.xml': authorization failed: Could not authenticate to server: ignored NTLM challenge, rejected Basic challenge (http://subversion)
	at org.apache.subversion.javahl.SVNClient.properties(Native Method)
{noformat}
From the above example error, FishEye/Crucible is started by the user "klfoong" and using the credential for the user "klfoong" in the repository setting to have NTLM authentication with Subversion server.

However, due to the credential is not cached, FishEye/Crucible keep on getting password from the repository setting till it hit the limit and stop getting password from the repository setting which will have authentication error during the request.

h3. Expected Results
FishEye/Crucible should save the user "klfoong" credential in the cache if Native Subversion Client is used.

h3. Workaround
As a workaround, we will need to login to the machine hosting FishEye/Crucible as user "klfoong" and perform a simple command like "svn info [http://subversion|http://subversion/]" so that the credential will be cached in "C:/Users/klfoong/AppData/Roaming/Subversion".

However, if there are hundred repositories in FishEye/Crucible with different Subversion domain, we need to run the same "svn info" command for all those repositories with different Subversion domain. (This is how Native Subversion Client save the credential. It save it based on host name.) In this case, the following Python script can help:
{code:java}
#!/usr/bin/python

import os
import sys
import getopt
import subprocess
import xml.etree.ElementTree

def main(argv):
    opts, args = getopt.getopt(argv,"hc:")
    for opt, arg in opts:
        if opt == "-c":
            config = arg

    print 'Using "' + config + '"'
    print 'Processing repositories:'

    root = xml.etree.ElementTree.parse(config).getroot()
    for repository in root.iter('repository'):
        svn = repository.find('svn')
        if svn is not None:
            auth = svn.find('auth')
            url = svn.get('url')
            if auth is not None:
                username = auth.get('username')
                password = auth.get('password')
                devnull = open(os.devnull, 'w')
                info = subprocess.call('svn info ' + url + '@HEAD --non-interactive --username ' + username + ' --password ' + password, shell=True, stdout=devnull, stderr=devnull)
                if info == 0:
                    print '[DONE]', url
                else:
                    print '[FAIL]', url
            else:
                print '[SKIP]', url, '(no auth)'


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main(sys.argv[1:])
{code}
This Python script will parse {{config.xml}} and execute {{svn info}} command against each SVN repository that has credentials defined. This should generate the files in {{svn.simple}} directory automatically, so it won't be needed to run that command manually anymore, for each repository.
 To run this Python script:
{noformat}
python PATH_TO_PYTHON_SCRIPT -c PATH_TO_CONFIG_XML
{noformat}
To make it worse, if the user "klfoong" password in Active Directory needs to be changed periodically, we will need to run the "svn info" command for all those repositories again.

Please refer to this [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHKB/SVN+is+requesting+password+too+often+for+realm] for more details

fields.description:
A very long string inside a file will cause a {{java.lang.StackOverflowError}} for files in repository when trying to view the source of this file or trying to add it to a review.

The following is shown in the logs:
{noformat}
2014-09-02 17:47:41,707 WARN  [qtp1829860190-171 ] org.eclipse.jetty.servlet.ServletHandler ServletHandler-doHandle - Error for /browse/merc/WFScheduleXMLTest.cs
java.lang.StackOverflowError
	at java.util.regex.Pattern$LazyLoop.match(Pattern.java:4730)
	at java.util.regex.Pattern$GroupTail.match(Pattern.java:4615)
	at java.util.regex.Pattern$BranchConn.match(Pattern.java:4466)
	at java.util.regex.Pattern$CharProperty.match(Pattern.java:3694)
	at java.util.regex.Pattern$Branch.match(Pattern.java:4502)
	at java.util.regex.Pattern$GroupHead.match(Pattern.java:4556)
	(...)
{noformat}

h3.Steps to Reproduce
# Create a file which highlights a string (in my test I used a .cs file).
# Define a long string (e.g. assigning it to a variable).
# Save and commit it to the repository.
# Have this file indexed by FishEye and try viewing its content.

The file used to test this is attached (*test.cs*).

h3.Workaround
* Break the long line in smaller lines.

OR

* Increase the thread stack size by increasing the -Xss JVM parameter (e.g. "-Xss2m"). This can be set in the *FISHEYE_OPTS* environment variable (refer to [Environment Variables|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Environment+variables] for further information on this). Please notice that increasing the thread stack size will allocate more memory for each thread, so Out of Memory errors may happen after increasing this setting if you do not have enough memory allocated for FishEye.
fields.summary: Long string will cause a java.lang.StackOverflowError for files in repository

fields.description:
Currently to trigger a repository re-index, Fisheye requires that the user has admin permissions for the entirety of Fisheye. This is fine when said indexing is done on a polling or manual push-button basis.
The REST API however, provides a very convenient way to automatically trigger an incremental index for example, as part of a post-commit hook in an SCM repo.

However, if authentication is used as part of the REST API, the user in question must have full admin privileges for the Fisheye instance.
Such privileges also allow the user to carry out destructive operations, such as deleting a repository, permissions schemes,users,groups,review projects, etc.

Ideally there'd be a new subset of admin permissions for such automation use. That or breaking up the admin permissions such that each operation (i.e., delete a group, create a user, list permission schemes) can be granted on an ad-hoc basis to individuals. This would be similar to how the finer grained permissions work in Confluence, Jira and Bambo. In fact, Crucible already uses permission schemes, so it's really just Fisheye missing the granularity level.

Another idea is perhaps the idea of a "repository admin" permission on a per-repository basis, such that all repository level operations (scan,start,enable,disable,stop,reindex-(source/reviews/linecount/search/discussions),scan-cvs,rescan-metadata) are available to defined users/groups on a per repository basis. Only a full Fisheye admin could delete a repository.
fields.summary: Increase Fisheye permission granularity

fields.description:
Despite some time spent bisecting the Fisheye source tree I haven't been able to identify the exact commit that is responsible, but I have identified that this issue was first introduced in Fisheye 3.1.

h3. The problem
The P4Scanner.indexRevisions method builds up a list of changesets until the list is larger than the batch size.  It then passes them off to the indexBatch() method.  Since 3.1 the list is not cleared after the batch is indexed and so all changesets that have been indexed so far are re-passed to the indexBatch method
fields.summary: Performance regression for perforce indexing from 2.9 to 3.4

fields.description:
Currently, if FishEye/Crucible is configured to use JIRA for user management, the FishEye/Crucible users passwords are just stored in the database used by JIRA.
So, if someone wants to switch to built-in authentication, removing the JIRA authentication from FishEye and switching the users authentication type to Built-In won't be enough. The users still won't be able to login, because their passwords won't be stored in the database used by FishEye/Crucible.

For example, this is part of a local {{cru_user}} database table from a local FishEye/Crucible 3.5.0 instance:
||CRU_USER_ID||CRU_USER_NAME||CRU_EMAIL||CRU_PASSWORDHASH||CRU_AUTHTYPE||CRU_DISPLAYNAME||
|1|fkraemer|fkraemer@atlassian.com|\{PKCS5S2}wer68f796hfd0EoFPyZQ5wJPd/bFonoYo7jb2Q/Br4M5Izs/U/xu468SN|1|Felipe Kraemer|
|2|user1|user1@atlassian.com|(null)|6|User 1|
As can be seen:
* The user {{fkraemer}} is Built-In (as per {{CRU_AUTHTYPE=1}}) and the user {{user1}} is from JIRA/Crowd (as per {{CRU_AUTHTYPE=6}}).
* The user {{fkraemer}} has a password configured, while the password from {{user1}} is blank.

In order to make this work nowadays, the passwords stored in the database used by JIRA need to be manually updated in the database used by FishEye/Crucible, user per user.

For instance, these would be the steps to accomplish that:
# Connect to the JIRA database and run this query (based on a JIRA 6.2 database schema, this might vary depending on the JIRA version):
{code:sql}
select user_name, email_address, credential from cwd_user;
{code}
My local results:
||USER_NAME||EMAIL_ADDRESS||CREDENTIAL||
|user1|user1@atlassian.com|\{PKCS5S2}wer68f796hfd0EoFPyZQ5wJPd/bFonoYo7jb2Q/Br4M5Izs/U/xu468SN|
# Copy/paste the results into a text file, spreadsheet, or something similar, in order to be used later on.
# Shutdown the FishEye/Crucible instance;
# Connect to the FishEye/Crucible database and:
## *Create a database dump!*
## Run this query once:
{code:sql}
update CRU_USER set CRU_AUTHTYPE = 1;
{code}
This will change the authentication type from JIRA/Crowd (6) to Built-In (1) for all the FishEye/Crucible users at once.
## Run this query for each user:
{code:sql}
update CRU_USER set CRU_PASSWORDHASH = '{PKCS5S2}wer68f796hfd0EoFPyZQ5wJPd/bFonoYo7jb2Q/Br4M5Izs/U/xu468SN' where CRU_USER_NAME = 'user1' and CRU_EMAIL = 'user1@atlassian.com';
{code}
(In the query above, remember to replace the values of the columns by the values copied in Step #2 above, from JIRA database)

After this whole process is finished, please follow these steps:
# Start the FishEye / Crucible instance;
# Go to {{FishEye Administration > Security Settings > Authentication}} and remove the JIRA/Crowd authentication.
# Try to login with a user that was previously authenticating in JIRA side.

----
However, the above suggestion is for JIRA/Crowd. How to copy the passwords from other external authentication tools such as LDAP?

Suggestion to make this whole process much better:
When the user goes to {{FishEye Administration > Security Settings > Authentication}} and clicks the {{Remove}} link under {{JIRA/Crowd Authentication}} section, before removing the configuration he should be presented with a popup window or something similar containing two checkboxes saying something like:
- Copy the passwords from JIRA/Crowd into FishEye
- Switch the authentication method to Built-In for all users.
fields.summary: Better handle detaching users from external authentication

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
While creating a JIRA issue from a comment in a Crucible Review, I want the *Assignee field* to be displayed so that I can immediately assign the ticket to the appropriate user.

Currently the [supported fields for inline issue creation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Supported+fields+for+inline+issue+creation] list does not include the Assignee field. 

As a consequence, the customer has to create the JIRA issue first, then open the newly created JIRA issue from the Crucible user interface in JIRA and edit the Assignee from the JIRA user interface.

+Note+: The current Crucible version only displays the mandatory fields in JIRA in the Issue creation dialog as described on the [Creating JIRA issues from the review|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Creating+JIRA+issues+from+the+review] page.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add the possibility to display the *Assignee field* to the JIRA inline issue creation dialog.

As alternative, assign the JIRA issue to the author of the review.
fields.summary: I want the Assignee field to be available in Crucible, while creating a JIRA issue from a Crucible

fields.description:
FishEye inconsistently renders wiki markup in commit messages.

When viewing the activity stream (activity tap in a repository), wiki markup in the commit message is correctly rendered. For example, a reference to a changeset is rendered correctly in [^fisheye_wiki_changeset_good.png].

However, when viewing the actual changeset (clicking on the changeset number from the activity stream), wiki markup in the commit message is not rendered (and newlines are eliminated). For example, the changeset markup in [^fisheye_wiki_changeset_bad.png].
fields.summary: Inconsistent rendering of wiki markup

fields.description: At the moment the colours used to represent different repos in the activity graphs change per user which makes the graphs on the 'people' list rather less useful. It would be great if the colours could be configured per repo so all users have the same colour representing the same repo.

Migrating (e.g.) from HSQLDB to PostgreSQL requires a restart, because Active Objects must generate table names differently for PostgreSQL.

It would be nice to have a feature in FishEye for GitLab integration, so that those subdirectories would be automatically added as repositories, by simply specifying the parent directory (project) via the file:// protocol.

fields.description:
When the support.zip is created, Fisheye iterates over all the repositories to save their properties to the applicaiton-properties xml file.  Problem is, it still goes through the permission filter that blocks access if a user attempts to access something they don't have permission to see.

The filter should be changed to let anyone who is an admin access anything, even if the permissions would otherwise disallow it.
fields.summary: Fisheye fails to create a support.zip if application properties are ticked and the logged in admin user doesn't have permission to see all the repositories
Wrong icons for files on search page ("content" tab)

fields.description:
Fisheye needs to support MariaDB.  The major distros (particularly Redhat/Centos) have replaced MySQL with MariaDB.  Atlassian has until 2020 to get supported before the current distro version goes EOL; if they can't do it in significantly less than 6 years then I may need to start shopping around for a replacement code manager.  I plan to have our RHEL/CentOS 6 servers all upgraded by 2017 and if MariaDB is not supported then I will find it difficult to justify continuing to support Atlassian products.

Closing the ticket out as WONTFIX like you did with FE-5159 IS NOT AN ACCEPTABLE ANSWER.
fields.summary: Fisheye needs to support MariaDB

fields.description:
Currently, as per the [Supported Platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Supported+platforms] page, MySQL distributions supported are:
* MySQL Enterprise Server 5.1+
* MySQL Community Server 5.1+

The suggestion is to have support to [Percona's|http://www.percona.com/] distribution.
fields.summary: Add support to Percona's distribution of MySQL

An upgrade from an earlier version of FishEye/Crucible to 3.5.0 may break the admin screens if you have upgraded the Universal Plugin Manager Plugin to a newer version than is shipped with FishEye/Crucible 3.5.0.

The workaround for this is to remove the custom installed version of the Universal Plugin Manager Plugin, (see below).

After upgrading from 3.4.5 to 3.5.0, this error is printed in the web browser when you try to access the administration panel:

fields.description:
Description: A file is shown in the JIRA Source tab as belonging to a specific branch. When I click in the file to go to FishEye, it opens the file in FishEye, showing the diff to the previous commit, but it is not shown as being in the branch shown in JIRA, but in "All" branches. The repository used is Git. The steps to reproduce are as follows:
# Create a new branch in the Git repository (e.g. a branch called "test") from master.
# Change a file in the "test" branch and commit it using a smart commit referencing a JIRA issue. It will be shown in JIRA as follows:
!jira.png!
# Click in the name of the file to be taken to FishEye (in this case, click in "file"). It will be shown as follows:
* In FishEye 3.1.5:
!fecru1.png!
* In FishEye 3.4.4:
!fecru2.png!

- Note the diff between the current commit and previous one is shown - I think this is expected, is this right?
- The branch however is shown as *All*, which I believe is the bug, as the commit is related to the branch *test*.
fields.summary: Clicking in a FishEye file from JIRA should select the branch the commit exists on

fields.description:
In at least FishEye 3.4.3 and 3.5, a changeset containing the deletion of large files and also other changes, can lead to a diff being requests of SVN that includes the large files being deleted.

A customer pointed out that this is most likely due to a change between SVN 1.6 and 1.7 whereby diffs for deletions are now included in diff results by default unless a --no-diff-deleted flag is included in the diff command.

To reproduce, craft a commit with a directory where only the following files:
* 1 very large deleted file, which is deleted
* 2 normal files that are modified

To be clear there can be as many deleted and modified files as you like, as long as there are _more_ modifications than deletions.  This is required to trigger a bulk-diff as opposed to a file-by-file diff.

Note that any exclusions in the directory will also trigger a file-by-file diff and avoid the bug.
fields.summary: Large deleted or added files can lead to OutOfMemoryError (OOME)

fields.description:
SCENARIO:
When using the fecru installer and disabling Crucible we have found that the AD connector ignores the configured Truststore and instead uses the Java runtime's Truststore

ERROR MESSAGES:
2014-07-17 17:55:49,884 ERROR - Communication error with LDAP
com.cenqua.fisheye.user.AuthenticationException: Problem getting the initial LDAP context
...<truncated>...
Caused by: javax.naming.CommunicationException: simple bind failed: <redacted>:3269 [Root exception is javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: sun.security.validator.ValidatorException: PKIX path building failed: sun.security.provider.certpath.SunCertPathBuilderException: unable to find valid certification path to requested target]


STEPS TO REPRODUCE:
* Using the Fisheye Crucible installer (fecru) configure HTTPS with custom key and trust store.
* Configure AD authentication over ldaps
* Disable Crucible.
* Restart fecru 
* The AD lookup will stop working and start erroring

WORKAROUND:
import the Truststore into the Java runtime's Truststore 'cacerts'
fields.summary: Fisheye is ignoring the configured truststore and reverting to the Java runtime's cacerts

Confirmed this is not only IE11, this is Windows 8, and does affect both IE10 and IE11.

h3. Workaround
Windows 8 users need to use Chrome or Firefox to access admin when using admin password

h3. Description
I clicked administration in the footer to log in as admin.  This works in Chrome.
In IE11 the screen presented is completely blank.

However I can log in as a named user using the Log In link and screen.

!http://monosnap.com/image/8ANFLJhVLmXXkV3F5TR2MbY6cv04UE.png!

fields.description:
Due to Java 8 InetAddress.getLocalHost().getHostName() returning localhost instead of the actual host name, the siteURL needs to be explicitly set when running on Java 8. 

If this is not set, Fisheye cannot be run confidently as all links provided to external apps, like email and other system integrations might be affected. 

Workaround is to explicitly set site URL in server settings.
fields.summary: SiteURL default setting does not work when using java 8

fields.description: It is possible for the 'p4 branch -o ...' command to return a non-zero exit status for some branches if there are problems with a repo. This should just ignore the branch, not stop indexing of the repo.
fields.summary: Failing to get the details of a branch spec should not stop a p4 repo from indexing

fields.description:
Our Stash repositories are labelled on a per Stash Project basis e.g.

Project 1

- Server

Project 2

- Server

At the moment when you add Server from Project 1 it automatically gets the name "server". Not very informative in our case.

When you then add Server from Project 2 you get the option to specify a name because this would cause a duplicate.

It would be great if same dialog opened offering to enter a custom name for all Stash repository additions, not just duplicates.

Even defaulting to Project-1-Server would be better.
fields.summary: Stash repository integration custom naming

fields.description:
It seems that not all errors related to the repositories are shown in the Admin UI. Usually these errors are shown in red blocks as follows:
!error.png!

One example that seems not to show up is the error described by [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHKB/Git+repository+indexing+fails+because+it+cannot+delete+the+branch+which+you+are+currently+on], so the state of the repository keeps as "Running" and the user doesn't know there is an issue to be fixed.
fields.summary: Improve the way errors are shown for repositories in the Admin UI

fields.description:
See attached git repository exhibiting this issues - tested on 3.4.5 stable and 3.5.0 snapshot.  The problem is with the file permission change.  Having binary file and new change to it that doesn't change content but only file permissions, leads to GitDiffParser to assume the file is binary, because git diff output doesn't contain line starting with "Binary file" phrase.
See:
{noformat}
piotrs@mbp-swiety git (master) $ git log -- chmod
commit b6e6880dfdd7019c76d0def427836b2ed9244f20
Author: Piotr Święcicki <pswiecicki@atlassian.com>
Date:   Mon Jul 7 10:22:49 2014 +0200

    removed image file

commit 158063eb99683fdb932eb1528ff1fcb852a2bca6
Author: Piotr Święcicki <pswiecicki@atlassian.com>
Date:   Mon Jul 7 10:21:32 2014 +0200

    permissions changed

commit fbdc43600674af55ce612e2e847c679403f3a4e0
Author: Piotr Święcicki <pswiecicki@atlassian.com>
Date:   Mon Jul 7 10:20:09 2014 +0200

    image file added


# changeset 158063e changed only file permission, FishEye assumed it is text file
piotrs@mbp-swiety git (master) $ git diff fbdc43600674af55ce612e2e847c679403f3a4e0..158063eb99683fdb932eb1528ff1fcb852a2bca6
diff --git a/chmod/icn_newerrevision.gif b/chmod/icn_newerrevision.gif
old mode 100644
new mode 100755
{noformat}
fields.summary: binary file detection in git get lost on file permission changes

fields.description:
As documented on https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Configuring+the+database+connection+pool FishEye / Crucible has a default connection max age of 0, which behaves as "forever".

This leads to resources being unnecessarily consumed beyond the application's requirements.

It also leaves the product more open than necessary to any memory leaks in the database drivers.
fields.summary: The default connection pool configuration holds connections forever

fields.description:
Since Git 1.6, there has been support for adding notes to git objects, without changing the commit. It gives you a nice way of adding in metadata without change the content itself.

See http://git-scm.com/blog/2010/08/25/notes.html and https://www.kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/git-notes.html for more information on this function.

It is not currently possible through the GUI or property files to change the commands of how it does the git repo slurps.  In order to pull in any notes, you would have add refs/notes/*:ref/notes/* as part of the git fetch step I assume that this is only possible right now by taking the Fisheye/Crucible source code and making a custom build.

If a plugin can read git notes, it's then possible to save off data from a Crucible inspection (like inspection credit, comments, signoffs, etc) into the git notes so that there is much less impact to the Crucible database.

A set of plugins that I help maintain coordinates information between JIRA, Crucible, and Bamboo about what commits have been inspected, what has been waived, and what is ready for a build. 

Having the ability to have Fisheye/Crucible read off some metadata and potentially write it in a custom plugin would give plugin writers more ways of sharing data between Atlassian products, plugins, and homegrown applications.
fields.summary: Fisheye and Crucible support Git Notes

fields.description: Currently only SVN allows the user to start working with latest revisions before the indexing is complete. The suggestion is to implement for Git something similar to the [Pipelined Indexing|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Pipelined+indexing] offered for SVN.
fields.summary: Implement feature similar to the SVN Pipelined Indexing for Git

fields.description: Currently, the Smart Commits is implemented to activated only on Repositories not Branches. It would be great if the smart commit is able to be configured in certain branches, not only repositories. Therefore, when a smart commits is executed, until the branch is not enabled for smart commits, then it will do nothing. Until the code is being reviewed and merges into a branch the smart commits would not activate, this will prevent to reopen an issue in JIRA when the code is somehow need to be re do.
fields.summary: Smart Commits to executed on certain branches.

fields.summary: Add support to the G1 Garbage Collector

fields.description:
If FishEye backup process is interrupted the partially prepared backup file stays on the file system.  There is no indication it is incomplete backup file so gives false indication of safety.   
This was observed on the dog food instance when automated deployment job to upgrade with a snapshot build was run while backup was in progress.   

Few options for consideration:
 * refuse to shutdown instance when backup procedure is in progress (and provide --force option to force shutdown)
 * delete temporary backup file if backup process didn't finish with success
 * or better use temporary name of backup file while building it and rename to a final name only when backup process completed successfully 

{noformat}
# unzip -l backup_fisheye_dev2014_06_23.zip
Archive:  backup_fisheye_dev2014_06_23.zip
  End-of-central-directory signature not found.  Either this file is not
  a zipfile, or it constitutes one disk of a multi-part archive.  In the
  latter case the central directory and zipfile comment will be found on
  the last disk(s) of this archive.
unzip:  cannot find zipfile directory in one of backup_fisheye_dev2014_06_23.zip or
        backup_fisheye_dev2014_06_23.zip.zip, and cannot find backup_fisheye_dev2014_06_23.zip.ZIP, period.
{noformat}
fields.summary: no indication on interrupted backup

fields.description:
If MaxNewSize is not defined in FISHEYE_OPTS Fisheye sets -XX:MaxNewSize=128m which may be downside. JVM by default calculates MaxNewSize from NewRatio (=2) which leads MaxNewSize to be 1/3 of Xmx.

Conclusion - remove default -XX:MaxNewSize=128m JVM option

Default -Xmx is 1024m and MaxPermSize is 256m which seem to be fine
fields.summary: Review default JVM options

fields.description: Currently all the commits of a chosen date are included in the Review Coverage report. The idea is to allow specific commits to be excluded from the report, so that they do not appear as part of the review percentage.
fields.summary: Ability to exclude specific commits from the Review Coverage report

fields.description:
According to the Mercurial [documentation|http://mercurial.selenic.com/wiki/Nodeid], the short-form of commit hashes should be the first 12 characters. We're currently only displaying the first 7 characters throughout FishEye.

For Git, it's [recommended|https://lkml.org/lkml/2013/9/30/365] to use 12 characters as well.
fields.summary: HG and Git short commit hashes should be 12 characters

fields.description:
When the user base is managed by JIRA and the Username of a user is changed, the User Mapping of this user gets blank in the column {{User}}. When editing the User Mapping, it does not seem it is correctly mapped, so maybe User Mappings should be reviewed when the user base is re-synchronized.

Steps to reproduce:
# Have a repository in FishEye with at least one commiter to test.
# Create a user in JIRA (e.g. Username = "grefosco"). JIRA used is in version 6.2.5.
# Configure FishEye Authentication to use JIRA (create JIRA User Server, connect FishEye to it, synchronize groups, etc). The only setting I changed from default was {{When synchronisation happens}}, checking the option {{Copy new users and changes to existing users}}.
# In FishEye, go to {{User Mappings}} and create one for the JIRA user {{grefosco}} and commiter {{grefosco}}.
# In JIRA, edit the user, changing its Username to "gustavorefosco".
# In FishEye, go to Authentication settings and run a Re-Sync. Ensure the new Username is showing up in FishEye.
# Go to {{User Mappings}}. The column {{User}} is blank.
fields.summary: User mapping goes wrong when changing user's Username in JIRA

fields.description:
In the activity stream (e.g. fisheye dashboard page) activity stream items are grouped by changeset id and timestamp only.  So if same changeset is found in different repositories it will be shown only once.
This behaviour seems acceptable for DVCS where hashes are meant to be unique. Having same DVCS repository indexed in few different fisheye repositories user currently see this item once only. 
But this becomes problematic for svn for example where commit numbers are generated sequentially.  Two unrelated commits made in two repositories with the same number and same timestamp would be grouped together.  This is rather unlikely to happen with developers committing changes, but more likely with svnadmin dump/load activities where svndumpfilter was used to modify the history
fields.summary: Activity Stream items group unrelated commits

fields.description:
A starter license restricts the number of running repositories to 5, but under certain circumstances, you will see an error when adding a new repository when you only have 4 running. Attached is a screenshot showing a 5th running repository that was not started because the error that starter licenses are not allowed to have more than 5 running repositories appeared. 

*Steps to Reproduce*

# Add 5 repositories to FishEye with a Starter license
# Stop or disable one of these repositories, you'll now have 4 running and 1 stopped or disabled
# Add an additional repository and you'll see an error message stating: 

{noformat}Failed to start repository <repo_name>: com.cenqua.fisheye.LicensePolicyException: Cannot start repository six: your license only allows up to 5 running repositories.{noformat}

The below error is in the logs:

{noformat}2014-06-11 13:50:53,717 ERROR [qtp1518970960-190 ] fisheye RepositoryAdminRpcServiceImpl-generateMsgAndLogRepoActionFailure - Failed to start repository one: com.cenqua.fisheye.LicensePolicyException: Cannot start repository one: your license only allows up to 5 running repositories.
com.atlassian.fisheye.spi.admin.services.RepositoryConfigException: com.cenqua.fisheye.LicensePolicyException: Cannot start repository one: your license only allows up to 5 running repositories.{noformat}

*Workaround*

* Disable the repositories that you don't want indexed
* Restart the FishEye server
* Your 5 enabled repositories should now be running
fields.summary: Error adding 5th running repository with Starter license

fields.description:
I know, I know. Why would we have a line break in the branch name?

We get the following exception while indexing one of our mercurial repositories:

{code}
Repository index failed due to error com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.RepositoryClientException:
com.atlassian.fisheye.dvcs.handler.DvcsProcessException:
Error while communicating with VCS:
com.atlassian.fisheye.dvcs.handler.DvcsProcessException:
Error while communicating with VCS:
com.atlassian.utils.process.ProcessException:
While executing: "D:\TortoiseHg\hg.exe --config extensions.felog=D:\CrucibleFishEyeHomeDirectory344\python\hg\hgfelog\hgfelog.py --config ui.verbose=false felog 6c9253451fe7554950ecfe1fdbd2f99897587aa3 -p -m" in [D:\CrucibleFishEyeDataStore\var\cache\SurveyDisplay\clone] com.atlassian.utils.process.ProcessException:
java.lang.RuntimeException:
Match failed:
string [mpovement to required responses on surveys], pattern [A:(.*)]
java.lang.RuntimeException:
Match failed:
string [mpovement to required responses on surveys], pattern [A:(.*)]
{code}

Examining that changeset I see:

{code}
>hg log -r 6c9253451fe7554950ecfe1fdbd2f99897587aa3

changeset:   118:6c9253451fe7
branch:      LD-1995 I
mpovement to required responses on surveys
parent:      116:5ed6594f9f8f
user:        Anonymity Protected <DueToFatFingered@Commit.com>
date:        Wed Jan 09 10:20:34 2013 -0600
summary:     Added changes to required responses on surveys.
{code}

Someone fat fingered a commit and pushed it and now it's part of our immutable mercurial history forever.

The fact that mercurial *allows* this means that fisheye should support it, though :(
fields.summary: Exception when indexing repository that has linebreak in branch name

fields.description:
When sharing a changeset from a changeset page (e.g. /changelog/FE-git?cs=fde0161b249aba09fa3ee1407ea40a951fd62ff7) on version 3.5.0-SNAPSHOT I got the email stating:
"Piotr Święcicki shared a repository with you:" with a link to the right changeset.
Version 3.4.4 used the same message, but version 2.8.1 used more adequate message:
"Xxxx shared a changeset from "3.1-SNAPSHOT" with you:"

when user is sharing a link to particular changeset rather than the whole repository itself FishEye could use different message, like FishEye 2.8.1 did.
fields.summary: improve changeset share mail content
